summary: Humans demonstrated an aggregate accuracy of 60.3% in detecting AI-generated images, with class-conditional analysis revealing superior performance in identifying real images (67.8%) compared to AI-generated images (52.8%). This difference was primarily due to an authenticity bias, leading participants to more often label AI images as real rather than vice versa. A modest upward drift in human detection accuracy was also observed over the 55-week deployment period.

claims.claim_text: Humans achieved an aggregate accuracy of 60.3% in detecting AI-generated images.
claims.uncertainty_annotation: High: Uses definitive language ("achieved") and precise numerical data.

claims.claim_text: Class-conditional accuracy was 67.8% for real images and 52.8% for AI images.
claims.uncertainty_annotation: High: Uses definitive language ("was") and precise numerical data, indicating a direct measurement or finding.

claims.claim_text: A modest upward drift in human detection accuracy was observed over the 55-week deployment.
claims.uncertainty_annotation: High: States a direct observation ("was observed"), indicating a definite finding or trend.

claims.claim_text: Participants exhibited an authenticity bias, more often labeling AI-generated images as real than real images as AI-generated.
claims.uncertainty_annotation: High: Uses definitive language ("exhibited") to describe a clearly observed characteristic or behavior.

pico_elements.intervention: Forced-choice classification task to distinguish AI-generated images from real images
pico_elements.comparison: Detection accuracy for real images versus AI-generated images; implicitly compared against chance performance (50%)
pico_elements.outcome: Aggregate accuracy, class-conditional accuracies (real vs. AI), longitudinal accuracy trends over 55 weeks, and patterns in confusion matrix (authenticity bias)

quality_scores.justification: The study is a large-scale, open-source web application deployment collecting observational data on human perception from self-selected participants over 55 weeks. While it has a longitudinal aspect, its core design is akin to a large-scale cross-sectional behavioral study, lacking random assignment or a control group typical of higher-quality designs like RCTs or controlled cohort studies.
